issue.title: NUnitLite Unification

milestone.title: 3.0Alpha3
milestone.description: The third Alpha release of NUnit 3.0.

issue.body: There is no single point where all the differences are listed. We need this in order to decide about future support for NUnitLite.

body:
This appears to have removed the CLR_2_0 conditional define from the CF builds, yet that conditional is still used in tests in NUnit2XmlOutputWriterTests.cs.

Is that going to be a problem when the !NETCF is removed from that conditional?

It's very odd because I did a search for CLR_2_0 and it appeared unused. It
was an old definition used under NUnit V2...

OK, checking I see that NUnit2XmlOutputWriterTests is not part of the CF
solution at all. So technically, no problem.

Of course, it _should_ be part of the solution but I think the test was
only added recently to the nunitlite builds and I didn't add it to CF. At
some point we should add it and fix it.

The expression (CLR_2_0 || CLR_4_0) goes back to when we were building V2
for .NET 1.0 and 1.1 and should also be removed. However, I don't see why
we would remove !NETCF since DateTime.TryParse() isn't availble.

On Thu, Nov 6, 2014 at 11:47 AM, oznetmaster notifications@github.com
wrote:

> This appears to have removed the CLR_2_0 conditional define from the CF
> builds, yet that conditional is still used in tests in
> NUnit2XmlOutputWriterTests.cs.
> 
> Is that going to be a problem when the !NETCF is removed from that
> conditional?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/328#issuecomment-62039486.

Because we should do what I did in my CF build, which was to do exactly what every CF program does – put DateTime.Parse in a try/catch block to do the same test. 

For example:

```
        [Test]

        public void TestResults_HasValidDateAttribute ()

              {

              string dateString = RequiredAttribute (topNode, "date");
```

#if NETCF || CLR_4_0

```
        DateTime date;
```

#if NETCF

```
              bool bOK = false;

              try

                    {

                    date = DateTime.Parse (dateString);

                    bOK = true;

                    }

              catch (Exception)

                    {

                    }

        Assert.That(bOK, "Invalid date attribute: {0}", dateString);
```

#else

```
        Assert.That(DateTime.TryParse(dateString, out date), "Invalid date attribute: {0}", dateString);
```

#endif

#endif

```
              }
```

Sent: Friday, November 7, 2014 4:03 AM
To: nunit/nunit
Cc: oznetmaster
Subject: Re: [nunit] Use .NET Stopwatch class for compact framework builds (#328)

It's very odd because I did a search for CLR_2_0 and it appeared unused. It 
was an old definition used under NUnit V2... 

OK, checking I see that NUnit2XmlOutputWriterTests is not part of the CF 
solution at all. So technically, no problem. 

Of course, it _should_ be part of the solution but I think the test was 
only added recently to the nunitlite builds and I didn't add it to CF. At 
some point we should add it and fix it. 

The expression (CLR_2_0 || CLR_4_0) goes back to when we were building V2 
for .NET 1.0 and 1.1 and should also be removed. However, I don't see why 
we would remove !NETCF since DateTime.TryParse() isn't availble.

wrote:

> NUnit2XmlOutputWriterTests.cs.

> conditional? 
>

> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/328#issuecomment-62039486. 

—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/328#issuecomment-62041832 .  https://github.com/notifications/beacon/AFh64cWGh1sxLW-YtwTHraHio18SJzI9ks5nK8tigaJpZM4C2FPI.gif

Yes, of  course. But if we made a change to enable it to run under NETCF,
then we'd remove the !NETCF, wouldn't we?

The main point is that the file you are talking about isn't part of the CF
build right now.

wrote:

> Because we should do what I did in my CF build, which was to do exactly

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub <
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/328#issuecomment-62041832> . <
> https://github.com/notifications/beacon/AFh64cWGh1sxLW-YtwTHraHio18SJzI9ks5nK8tigaJpZM4C2FPI.gif>
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/328#issuecomment-62042834.

But then it would still have the (CLR_2_0 || CLR_4_0) and would not compile.

You are right, it is not important now.

But it seems like it should be fixed when it is discovered, and not left for a future possible problem.

Yes, of course. But if we made a change to enable it to run under NETCF, 
then we'd remove the !NETCF, wouldn't we? 

The main point is that the file you are talking about isn't part of the CF 
build right now.

Sure... and I didn't because it's not part of mine. :-)

If I had seen it, I would have removed the CLR defines, because it's a
small thing. Now that I know about it, I'll do a search of the main
solution and remove any that are there and just post a fix.

OTOH I think adding missing test case classes to the CF build is something
to do as a separate PR.
